p: Conversation is not a simple process of transmitting information. It follows rules that take into account characteristics of the speaker and the listener, and the common knowledge of speaker and listener ( Grice, 1975). Much if not most of remembering occurs during social interactions and conversations, and is thus shaped by both individual memory processes ( Roediger and DeSoto, 2015) and conversational rules. Depending on the social situation, what is remembered is changed and adapted to the affordances of the situation, including features of the audience ( Hirst and Echterhoff, 2012; Rechdan et al., 2016). Remembering in a social context can thus be understood as a co-construction process ( Pasupathi, 2001), whereby speakers are influenced by their schemata as well as by the requirements of the context and the expectations of the audience ( Grice, 1975). Co-construction is an adaptive process characterized as audience tuning by Hellmann et al. (2011).
